None looks as exposed as CYBG though, whose capital buffer is getting eaten by compensation payments to people who don't read small print, much of which will probably end up with no-win-no-fee type claims processing companies.

Grouchmonkey Morning all
BE11:11am

Here's Caz.

BE11:12am

After the market, CYBG announced an additional PPI provision of c£300-
£450m for 4Q19e, which implies a hit of c130-190bps of CT1 and we now
estimate CT1 at 12.8% FY19 vs the 13% target and 11% minimum. CYBG’s
charges are significantly higher than anticipated and are driven by an industry wide spike in claims/ information requests in the run-up to the August deadline. CYBG is more impacted due to lower scale and hence higher cost of processing claims compared to the bigger UK banks, in our view. We note that similar to RBS, the range of cost outcomes is extremely wide with the
group assuming a 5-12% uphold rate on the last minute flood of claims which are yet to be analysed. We are cutting our estimates significantly, now assuming a loss of £318m in 2019 and also reduce FY 20-22 EPS by 16-20%
for lower NIM and normalising provisions. The stock trades at 5.4x P/E ‘21e, 0.6x PTNAV ‘19e for an underlying RoTE of 10.7% '21e, representing a
c10% PE discount to UK domestics.

Soundbuy Where's this PPI dosh been spent over the years.... Gin, decking, spiralizers.......?
11:12 am
BE11:12am

CYBG received more than eight months’ worth of Information
Requests in August with c340k in aggregate over five weeks, o.w.
c120k were in the final three days. Further, the Group received c5k
complaints/week during the first four weeks of August and an additional
2k complaints in the final three days. Of the £300-450m estimated PPI
cost, c£100m relates to additional complaints (incl. Official Receiver),
c£100m relates to information request processing costs, and c£100-250m
relates to information request complaint costs which assumes a 5-12%
complaint conversion rate.

BE11:12am

We assume the final PPI cost at the mid-point of £375m for 4Q19,
resulting in CT1 reducing to 12.8% FY19e, just below the c13% CT1
target. We reduce our DPS estimates to 3p/3p/6p (from 6p/6p/12p) with
CT1 falling to 12.4% FY21e but above the Group’s 11% minimum. This
implies limited room on capital, should there be a meaningful turn in the
external environment.

BE11:12am

We reduce Adj EPS forecasts by 16-20% in FY20-22e driven by
lower NIM forecasts of 156bps/155bps FY20/21e reflecting our
estimates for the 4Q19e exit run-rate of 158bps and continued
competitive pressures. We forecast costs of £950m FY19e in line with
guidance, with CIR reducing annually from 57% FY19e to 50% FY21e,
but CoR normalizing from 24bps FY19e to 35bps FY21e. Our PT falls
to 150p from 200p, based on required CT1 at 12% and multiples inline
with our assumptions for other UK banks.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

(@Soundbuy: I've heard it suggested that there's a correlation with car sales.)

Shinshin "Hi, we understand that you were recently involved in an accident where you forgot to claim for your PPI before the deadline"
BE11:14am

And Barclays.

BE11:14am

Alongside read-across concerns for other UK banks (noting RBS’ pre-announcement of £600-900m PPI charges) this charge raises questions around CYBG’s capital, as well as the outlook for dividends and the targeted growth agenda.

Surplus capital now firmly off the table: With the pro-forma CET1 ratio now at or potentially below CYBG’s c13% target level, this firmly eliminates the prospect of surplus capital returns, which we believe some investors had been hoping for, and may require some moderation in market expectations for dividends (note: CYBG targets 50% dividend payout over the medium term, vs 10% of underlying earnings in 2018).

Soundbuy @BE - thinking of the school run that would make sense......
11:14 am
BE11:14am

Capital now arguably thin, could require capital management: We had already expected CYBG’s CET1 ratio to fall in 2020, impacted by restructuring charges/subdued profits alongside our continued expectations for CYBG to begin accruing a dividend deduction from capital in due course (something it doesn’t currently do in contrast to other UK banks) as its dividend policy becomes firmly established: based on the FY18 dividend this would take c40bp off year-end CET1. With sufficient headroom over its 11% minimum capital requirement (excluding any unknown PRA buffer), we don’t currently expect CYBG to respond by taking inorganic capital actions, although this may form part of the discussion over time.

Raises questions on growth outlook: This charge also raises questions in our mind on the business’ growth/investment agenda, and may require a reduced pace of investment spend, and slow RWA growth – which could hamper the targeted build in profitability towards 12% RoTE.

BE11:15am

We are cautious on the earnings outlook (with earnings estimates c10-15% below Refinitiv consensus) on expectations of weaker net interest margin (asset margin pressure, rising funding costs). We see an investment case driven primarily by cost take-out, that looks too similar to Lloyds/RBS, but without the sector-leading capital return underpin. However, valuation is subdued, at 6.4x BARC 2020e EPS, or 0.5x TNAV for a c8% 2020e ROTE, which should act as somewhat of a cushion (although shares likely to overreact near-term).

Pseudonym I think Lloyds already warned on this?
BE11:16am

The challenger banks really have been a fascinating experiment in reinventing something that's worse than the thing it's meant to disrupt.

BE11:21am

[BREXIT]

BE11:21am

Morgan Stanley:

11:21 am
BE11:21am

The government was defeated twice by Parliament yesterday. First, the Benn bill to prevent a no deal exit on October 31 cleared all the Commons stages last night. Second, the government failed to get the majority required to trigger early elections. We still expect elections before Brexit, perhaps in December. Benn bill completes Commons stages: The Benn bill, which requires the government to request an extension of the article 50 negotiating period to January 31 if a deal is not approved or Parliament does not vote to support a no deal outcome by October 19, ie just after the key European Council, was approved in the Commons by a clear majority. The bill will now go to the Lords. Here there is some risk that the bill could be held up, given the large number of amendments tabled. However, it seems unlikely that the Lords will stand in the way of the Commons, and we see it as likely that the bill will become law before prorogation next week. Early elections motion defeated: In response, PM Johnson moved a motion for early elections on October 15, ahead of the EU Council summit on October 17-18. However, to succeed, this vote needed the support of two-thirds of MPs, and this was not achieved, since the opposition said they would only support triggering elections once the Benn bill has been implemented, and the risk of no deal on October 31 has been taken off the table. Elections before Brexit: We see elections as the most plausible way to decide the way forward on Brexit and expect them to be held before Brexit. They might be triggered next week, once the Benn bill gets royal assent, for an October election. However, we think they may be more likely to be triggered after October 19 when an extension has been secured.

Viking1 Morning
BE11:22am

Goldman Sachs:

BE11:22am

In our view, today’s developments make clear that there is no majority in the current Parliament for a “no deal” Brexit on 31 October. We think it is doubtful that there is a simple majority in the current Parliament in favour of a general election before 31 October either. This leaves the current Prime Minister in place in the current Parliament until 31 October (unless he resigns), with current MPs presented with a binary choice between: (i) a Brexit deal in October, and (ii) a post-extension general election in November. Faced with that choice, Mr. Johnson’s flagship campaign pledge (to leave the EU on 31 October “come what may”) could well incentivise him to whip his own Conservative backbenchers in favour of the former, while the electoral threat posed by the Brexit Party could well incentivise a number of backbench Labour MPs to cast their vote in the government’s direction. Mr. Johnson has already demonstrated that he is prepared to remove the whip from those Conservative MPs who defy it. Allowing a pro-active majority to form in this way behind a Brexit deal could well also be in Mr. Corbyn’s interests, because Brexit would be delivered without the active support of the Labour leader.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

4. The “Kinnock amendment” this evening was passed without a vote among MPs in the House of Commons. As attached to the Benn Bill, this amendment means that any Article 50 extension, if agreed, would be used for the precise purpose of passing the latest version of former Prime Minister May’s Withdrawal Agreement Bill. In our view, this is a significant development because it allows space for a Brexit deal struck in mid-October to be swiftly ratified in the House of Commons. More importantly, it signals that at least 17 Labour MPs would be willing to support a cross-party compromise that delivers an orderly Brexit.
5. In our base case, there is no pre-Brexit general election and a Brexit deal is struck in October. In substance, we think that deal is unlikely to look very different from the Brexit deal already negotiated between the EU and the UK — a deal that was repeatedly rejected earlier in the year.

BE11:22am

[/BREXIT]

Maverick Morning all, a little late to the party but just wondered if anybody had any thoughts on this mornings article suggesting a merger between Otis Elevator and Schindler Holding?I've also noticed NMC Health continuing to look rosey since suggestions of a potential bidding war for a 40% stake....Any thoughts or added commentary will be greatly appreciated.

BE11:30am

Sector bad, valuation expensive.

BE11:31am

We are updating our estimates following the company’s FY19
results and factor in the closure of the US and Australian
operations. Rightly so, management is now focused on the UK
operations with Canada providing a free option. We believe the
structural growth opportunity for the UK business remains large and
online agents will continue to take share in the next few years.
However, with housing transactions stuck at historic lows, any property
agent operation (no matter if online or offline) suffers materially - and a
major improvement in underlying market developments is needed to
lift estimates and drive the shares. This appears unlikely to occur in the
short term given current political developments in the UK and we see
plenty of time for investors to revisit the investment case at a later
stage. Hence, we downgrade the shares from OW to N.

Soundbuy @Maverick - Otis Elevator and Schindler Holdings.....on the rise?

structure. With the involvement of Axel Springer’s tech teams,
Purplebricks is now reassessing it’s pricing structure across the UK
and we expect the upfront pricing model to change moderatelThe company is rethinking its current pricing
structure. With the involvement of Axel Springer’s tech teams,
Purplebricks is now reassessing it’s pricing structure across the UK
and we expect the upfront pricing model to change moderately

Valuation on arguably cautious estimates does not look overly
compelling at this point. The UK business is profitable and Group
profitability is only held back by investments in Canada, and closure
costs in the US and Australia in FY20. For FY21 we see an EBITDA
of £12m, increasing to £32m by 2023 – with material upside if the
UK housing market does improve. On our (we believe conservative)
estimates, the UK alone is generating £11m of EBITDA in 2020
(April Yr. end) which equates ~ to 30x EV/UK EBITDA (ex-cash)
for a +c35% 2020E-2022E EBITDA CAGR (UK).

Maverick Ahh appreciate that Bryce

As well as the difficulty around Schindler's structure, given the namesake and Bonnard families own 71% of the voting rights.

BE11:37am

Over to Liberum:

11:37 am
BE11:37am

In addition, there would be significant anti-trust issues in most geographies with Otis the clear global number 1 in an industry with 4 global players. Otis and Schindler would have a combined installed base of c.3.5m, or c.60% share of the global players. Talk of consolidation in the elevator industry has stepped up since Thyssenkrupp decided to IPO it's elevator business - we expect this business to be acquired/merged before it lists, with Kone the most likely buyer given the smaller geographical overlap. There has been talk for a long time of the elevator industry going from 4 to 3 global players, and perhaps this is Otis thinking of buying Schindler before Kone buys or merges with Thyssenkrupp as it’s very hard to see competition authorities allowing just 2 global players. So there is clear rationale for it, but a Kone-Thyssenkrupp tie up would still seem the most likely.

Plato the Cook It shouldn’t be difficult for an MP to decide between country and family. He should have read the job description
Blank canvas Have I missed something on ITV? or is it just background noise?

BE11:39am

Soundbuy ....though vols of late a tad meh.........
BE11:39am

As per Morgan Stanley.

11:39 am
BE11:40am

There has been continued speculation about a possible tie-up between Kone and thyssenkrupp elevators (covered by Alain Gabriel), on which we have previously written (see our note from 15th May 2019). Clearly, the announcement of the separation of Otis from United Technologies (covered by Rajeev Lalwani) and of the elevators asset from the rest of thyssenkrupp is creating waves in the industry. Note that the top 4 players (Otis, Schindler, Kone and thyssenkrupp) hold close to a 75% share of the new equipment installed globally, with significant geographic overlap. Please see our Global Elevators Playbook published in July for more details.A few facts: Otis and Schindler are respectively the #1 and #2 players in the global elevators industry. Otis had sales of almost $13bn in 2018, vs Schindler's c. $11bn, and EBIT of c. $2bn, vs Schindler's $1.3bn – a combination would therefore have made a giant in the elevators industry. The Schindler family and affiliates control 71% of Schindler's voting rights, and would therefore have a key role in any takeover/merger/partnership discussions.

Oh, and Future.

Future PLC (FUTR:LSE): Last: 1,308, up 116 (+9.73%), High: 1,400, Low: 1,286, Volume: 366.60k
11:45 am
BE11:45am

You'll remember the bear stuff around Future from a month or so ago. Poor quality, content stuffing, management overly rewarded for inorganic growth, all that.

BE11:46am

Well, today's statement ........ doesn't really matter to any of those arguments. But if the wheels are going to come off, they haven't yet.

BE11:47am

Here's Numis to summarise.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Management note that trading for the year in the Group's core operations has been stronger than previous expectations. The Group has experienced a positive performance from Amazon Prime Day related activity and strong ongoing trading in the US, with FX a further boost to earnings given recent sterling weakness. The Group continues to show positive momentum in revenue growth in all core areas and cash conversion remains excellent, with year end leverage expected to be under 1x. The statement ultimately confirms that full year EBITDA is now expected to be materially ahead of expectations.

BE11:47am

Audience growth continues to underpin the stronger revenue performance, performing well across the business. The integration of Purch is nearing completion with three key brands (Tomshardware.com, LiveScience.com and TopTenReviews.com) all migrated to Vanilla over the summer. Cyclingnews migrated to Vanilla at the end of August, with Future's new mountain bike brand Bikeperfect.com launched in beta in July.

BE11:48am

Estimates upgraded again. We put through a healthy underlying upgrade at the time of the Q3 trading update in July. We upgrade again here on the back of this strong statement, with higher revenue and EBITDA marginally offset by a higher tax charge given higher US profits. Our 2019E PBT/EPS increases to £49m/46.5p from £43.8m/41.7p with 2020E up to £55.1m/50.5p from £50.9m/47p. Despite our upgrade here we continue to believe 2020E to be modeled on a relatively cautious basis with upside risk as we move through the year.

11:47 am
BE11:48am

Future remains a key pick for 2019. We remain very comfortable with Future as a key pick in 2019. We increase our multiples based target to 1,470p (previous 1,315p) and reiterate our BUY.

BE11:49am

The argument here I guess is that we're wrong to talk about Future as a publisher because it's really just Moneysupermarket or Tripadvisor or whatever, earning commissions off purchase referrals.

BE11:50am

Which may be the only sustainable model left for journalism.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Here's Peel Hunt.

BE11:50am

Cash conversion continues to be excellent and as a result,
leverage at the year-end is expected to be under 1x. Today, we
upgrade our EPS for FY19 by 14% (company adjusted EPS by
11%) to reflect the trading update. Future has had an excellent
FY19, and we expect the company will continue to deliver. Buy.

11:54 am
BE11:55am

Here's Panmure.

A. M. (what's "high-speed packaging"?)
BE11:56am

As expected, Mpac Group has reported a solid set of interim numbers thanks to
exceptional growth in the US. In the first half of 2019, revenues grew by 62%
YoY, 43% YoY excluding the acquisition of Lambert Automation Group. This
translated to a strong jump in operating margin to 10% (H1/18: 0%). As a result,
we now expect FY19 PBT and EPS forecasts to be 28% and 34% above previous
estimates. However, we recognise that H1/19 results were helped by a higher
proportion of repeat projects. Investors should focus on the sustainable
progression in operating margins which we expect to rise from 2.8% in 2018 to
7.6% in 2021, consistent with management’s five-year plan. Notwithstanding
the deterioration in general economic climate, we maintain our FY20-21
forecasts and TP of 300p unchanged.

2s10s oh ok, #Cuba #Molins https://www.derryjournal.com/news/half-century-of-manufacturing-at-old-molins-and-mpe-site-to-end-tomorrow-1-7892321
Soundbuy .........just the association I meant.......and it provided some agency with 6 months work
BE11:56am

(@2s10s: it was in the 1900s, to be fair.)

11:56 am
BE11:56am

 A merica leads the way: H1/19 revenue in the America regions increased by 70% YoY,
with OE (original equipment) revenue nearly doubling. By sector, sales to the
Healthcare sector increased by over 200% YoY, driven by the large contracts won in
late 2018 and early 2019. Sales to the Food and Beverage and other markets also
showed steady progress. Pharmaceutical revenue was adversely affected by the
timing of contracts within the industry and is expected to recover in H2/19.
 O perational efficiency: OE gross margin in H1/19 increased sharply to 27.2% (H1/18:
18.0%) reflecting both the continuing execution of the bottom-up strategy and a
higher proportion of repeat projects delivered. As a result of the exceptional jump in
operating margin in H1/19 to 10%, we have raised our FY19 estimate by 1.8% to 8.3%,
which implies an operating margin of 6.2% in H2/19 (H1/18: 4.7%). This is more in line
with management’s long-term plan to steadily grow operating margins; we continue
to forecast operating margins to rise steadily from 2.8% in FY18 to 6.9% and 7.6% in
FY20 and FY21, respectively.

BE11:56am

ension: The IAS 19 valuation of the UK scheme at end-June showed a surplus of
£29.3m (£19.2m net of deferred tax), compared with a surplus of £20.5m (£13.2m net
of deferred tax) at end-December 2018. The main driver of the increase in the surplus
was the strong asset performance, partially offset by a decrease in the discount rate.
As reported previously, the actuarial deficit in the legacy ‘Molins UK Pension Fund’
scheme has been cut by half from £69.9m at 30 June 2015 to £35.2m at 30 June 2018
on a technical provisions basis. The actuarial deficit is now expected to be to be
eliminated in July 2024, compared to August 2029 under the previous valuation.

BE11:56am

O utlook and Valuation: The outlook statement is cautious and understandably so
given the macro-economic commentary. Management has also highlighted that FMCG
companies are under pressure to eliminate plastic in consumer products which are
leading to investment delays while new solutions are developed. However, Mpac
enjoys a strong balance sheet (we forecast net cash of £14m at end-2019) and is
looking to add to its Lambert acquisition. We continue to recommend BUY with a
target price of 300p which is based on 10x 2020 EPS.

https://www.ft.com...-99a4-b5ded7a7fe3f

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Jo Johnson, the brother of Britain’s prime minister Boris Johnson, is quitting politics with thinly-veiled attack on his leadership.

The universities minister, who has served as the MP for Orpington in Kent since 2010, announced on Thursday he would stand down at the next election.

“It’s been an honour to represent Orpington for 9 years & to serve as a minister under three PMs,” he tweeted.

BE12:06pm

Want RBC's global gold outlook? I mean, it's not directly related but gold and silver are basically the same, as I often tell the wife.

BE12:06pm

Falling real rates continue to provide the catalyst for higher gold prices and this week gold hit a six year
high of $1,555/oz, as global real rates continued to decline with an estimated $17 trillion in negative
yielding debt (Exhibit 7). Recession fears persist as the U.S. yield curve remains inverted and the 10-year
US Treasury yield fell to 1.47% on August 28th, versus 1.7% a month ago and 3.2% in Q4/2018. Spot
gold at ~$1,550/oz appears to be pricing in two further Fed rate cuts in 2019 and a continued dovish
outlook for 2020 (Exhibit 8).
The global macro backdrop suggests the near-term economic risks are to the downside, as the U.S.-
China trade war rhetoric remains elevated and geopolitical tensions in the Gulf of Oman remain intact.
Our near-term average gold price assumption of $1,500/oz for the remainder of 2019 and in 2020
(previously $1,350/oz) broadly reflects the view of our Commodity Strategy Team (see here). Our gold
price assumption for 2021 and 2022 is now $1,450/oz (was $1,300) and we have moved our long-term
gold price to $1,400/oz from $1,300/oz (Exhibit 3). We increase our silver price forecast for H2/19 to
$17.33/oz from $15.75/oz and our longer-term forecasts to $17.50/oz from $16.50/oz (page 13).
We expect gold prices to be driven by financial market sentiment, the outlook for the global economy
and expected actions by the Fed. We see tactical trading opportunities to buy the gold equities on any
weakness ahead of the upcoming FOMC meeting in September and the market’s current expectations
for a 25 bps rate cut. At this point gold appears to be pricing in no successful completion of a U.S.-China
free trade agreement before year end. We expect a seasonal rally in the gold price in the December-
January period as observed in each of the past 5 year-end periods.

BE12:07pm

We believe a new long-term floor price for gold has been established at $1,400/oz given the magnitude
that global real rates have declined, dovish global central bank outlooks and the policy direction of the U.S. administration regarding global trade and monetary policy. We highlight that 1. the risk to our gold price forecast remains skewed to the upside; and 2. the gold equities have lagged the gold price move and appear to be pricing in roughly a $1,400/oz flat gold price. At the current ~$1,550 spot price, the NA Senior gold producers have an average 33% return to our valuations, the Intermediate producers a 38% return and the Junior producers a 63% return. This suggests to us that there are opportunities for fundamental investors to achieve attractive returns investing in gold equities.

12:08 pm
BE12:08pm

And for the equity view .....

BE12:09pm

Generalists still underweight, London market tough... With price risk to the upside it is interesting to
note that generalists are still largely underweight or not involved in the sector. In part this is structural
given liquidity levels and relatively small market cap (our global producer coverage totals c. $285 bn
vs. Apple at c. $940 bn). Whilst concerns on capital allocation may be somewhat valid we continue to
think the industry could be in somewhat of a sweet spot of higher prices without the mandate (yet)
to carry our value destructive "actions". Despite the equity rally opportunities still exist for investors
willing to be contrarian. The London precious market remains a tough space due to its "challenged"
jurisdictional footprint, a lack of large cap exposures since Randgold's de-listing and a number of
high profile operational misses (e.g. Centamin in 2018, Fresnillo this year). However, Polymetal and
Hochschild do screen as attractive in our view. We also still think the potential "hedge" from London
listed precious equities to a weaker GBP due to Brexit also remains somewhat underappreciated.
Remaining selective here, preference for names with clear catalysts. Our gold equities have been
doing what they should and providing beta to the gold price with our average +51% move YTD
comparing to gold +20% and outperforming the GDX global gold miner index by +12%. We think
this can continue but remain selective towards the equities. Our preference is for companies that
have a consistent strategy, deliver operational performance in line with guidance and that have
clear, deliverable catalysts. In London Outperform rated Polymetal delivers a c. 4% dividend yield in
parallel with ounce growth. Hochschild has silver leverage and undervalued resource growth potential.
For global investors Outperform rated AngloGold screens well as a catalyst rich re-rating story and
Endeavour Mining can deliver deleveraging then a capital allocation pivot towards returns.
